pages.text_verbatim_title_block:
WADDELL ENGINEERING LTD.
STRUCTURAL MEMO
Wednesday, January 15, 2025
To: Bob McLean, Municipality of West Perth; CBO
From: Sam DesRoches, Waddell Engineering Ltd.
Project: Steel Beam at 26 Nelson St.
Location: 26 Nelson St, Mitchell, Ontario
Project No.: 25-01-083
119 Pinebush Road, Unit C, Cambridge, ON N1R 7J8 – Phone 519-267-6789
pages.general_notes_verbatim:
To whom it may concern,
Waddell Engineering Ltd. (WEL) has been retained to provide a structural review of the design for the project mentioned above.
Background:
A site inspection of the referenced project was conducted on January 14, 2025, by WEL personnel. During this inspection, it was discovered that the W200x21 steel beam in the basement was cut too short and is not supported by the foundation wall at each end. Instead, this beam was supported by a built-up 4 ply 2x6 post at both ends. This is shown in Figures 1 and 2 below.
pages.page_overview_summary: This page is a structural memo from Waddell Engineering Ltd. regarding a steel beam at 26 Nelson St. The memo describes a site inspection revealing that a steel beam in the basement is inadequately supported by temporary posts instead of the foundation wall. The document sets the context for the structural review and includes images of the existing conditions.

pages.text_verbatim_title_block:
WADDELL ENGINEERING LTD.
STRUCTURAL MEMO
Wednesday, January 15, 2025
119 Pinebush Road, Unit C, Cambridge, ON N1R 7J8 – Phone 519-267-6789
pages.general_notes_verbatim:
Design Loads:
The following design loads were used for the review of the installed steel beam in the basement. This beam is highlighted in Figure 3 above.
Dead load = 0.57 kPa
Live load = 1.90 kPa
pages.page_overview_summary: This page includes a plan view highlighting the basement beam that requires support. It specifies the design loads used for the review, indicating dead and live loads. The plan provides a visual reference for the location and context of the beam within the basement.

pages.text_verbatim_title_block:
WADDELL ENGINEERING LTD.
STRUCTURAL MEMO
Wednesday, January 15, 2025
119 Pinebush Road, Unit C, Cambridge, ON N1R 7J8 – Phone 519-267-6789
pages.general_notes_verbatim:
Proposed Repair:
The temporary wood post that was installed at each end of the beam shall be replaced with a telepost rated for a min factored load of 6,000 lbs. This post shall be installed as per the manufacturers recommendations and fastened to the bottom flange of the beam. The 2x4 stud wall that will be installed next to the foundation wall shall have a stud installed tight to against each side of the steel beam.
The strip footing shall be widened with a 36” x 18” x 10” thick footing installed below the post and doweled into the existing strip footing as shown in Figure 4.
Comments:
It is the opinion of Waddell Engineering Ltd. that the design is structurally adequate and agrees with the Ontario Building Code.
Any questions or comments can be directed to the writer.
Regards,
Sam DesRoches P.Eng.
pages.page_overview_summary: This page details the proposed repair for the basement beam support. It includes a diagram of the proposed footing and telepost installation. The repair involves replacing temporary wood posts with teleposts and widening the strip footing. The page concludes with a professional opinion that the design is structurally adequate.

The information, interpretations and conclusions in this report are based on WEL’s interpretation of conditions revealed through limited investigation conducted within a defined scope of services. No physical or destructive testing and no engineering calculations have been performed unless specifically mentioned in the report. Existing conditions which have not been record...
pages.page_overview_summary: This page outlines the limitations of the structural memo prepared by Waddell Engineering Ltd. It specifies the conditions under which the report can be used, the scope of the investigation, and the responsibilities of the parties involved. The page emphasizes the limitations of the findings due to the defined scope and reliance on provided information.
